Hi LinkedIn network,I’m actively seeking full-time opportunities as a Generative AI Engineer / Machine Learning Engineer / Applied AI Specialist where I can apply my expertise in deep learning, NLP, computer vision, and cloud-based AI deployments to build real-world, impactful solutions.With 5+ years of hands-on experience, I’ve designed and deployed machine learning systems that drive measurable business outcomes. Some highlights from my recent work:🔹 At Wesco International, I developed and deployed ML models for demand forecasting, B2B product recommendations, and anomaly detection, integrating them with AWS SageMaker, Airflow, and Docker. 🔹 Built real-time NLP pipelines using BERT, spaCy, and Hugging Face, improving sentiment analysis and customer support systems. 🔹 At Wissen Infotech, I focused on customer churn prediction and segmentation, leveraging XGBoost, LSTM, and deep NLP models to support financial services clients. 🔹 Deployed AI models into production with tools like MLflow, Power BI, and containerized services via FastAPI and Kubernetes. 🔹 Strong focus on end-to-end MLOps, from data ingestion and feature engineering to deployment and monitoring.📚 I hold a Master’s in Computer Science from Campbellsville University and I’m a certified TensorFlow Developer, passionate about transforming data into actionable intelligence.🛠️ Technical Stack: Python, TensorFlow, PyTorch, SageMaker, SQL, Docker, FastAPI, AWS, Azure, NLP (Transformers), CV (YOLO, OpenCV), Power BI, MLflow, GitHub Actions💡 I’m especially excited about roles involving Generative AI, AI in Supply Chain/Finance/Healthcare, and AI product engineering—but I’m open to all opportunities where I can make a meaningful impact!📩 Feel free to DM me or connect if you know of any openings or are hiring! 📧 Email: jaswanthr350@gmail.comLet’s build smarter solutions together. 🤖hashtaghashtag#OpenToWorkhashtag#AIJobshashtag#MachineLearninghashtag#GenerativeAIhashtag#NLPhashtag#ComputerVisionhashtag#DataSciencehashtag#SageMakerhashtag#FastAPIhashtag#MLflowhashtag#DeepLearninghashtag#AIEngineerhashtag#JobSearchhashtag#MLOpshashtag#AWShashtag#Python

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Hi LinkedIn network,I’m actively seeking full-time opportunities as a Generative AI Engineer / Machine Learning Engineer / Applied AI Specialist where I can apply my expertise in deep learning, NLP, computer vision, and cloud-based AI deployments to build real-world, impactful solutions.With 5+ years of hands-on experience, I’ve designed and deployed machine learning systems that drive measurable business outcomes. It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

dụng trong khoang xe trên thiết bị Edge như Qualcomm 8255 SoC.- Phối hợp với kỹ sư Computer Vision xây dựng mô hình AI chạy trực tiếp trên thiết bị và trình diễn PoC.- Đánh giá tính khả thi, tích hợp It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Planning a tech career pivot in 2025? Start with the right certification path.Whether you are aiming to be a Cloud Engineer or diving into the world of AI/ML, the certification you choose can make or break your entry into the field.This blueprint maps out the most relevant certification paths based on your target role, so you are not just collecting badges, you are building a strategic, hire-ready profile.Here is how it is structured:1. Cloud & Platform Engineers:Start with system and container fundamentals, followed by multi-cloud and orchestration certs to build scalable systems.2. DevOps & MLOps Engineers:Focus on pipelines, automation, containerization, and CI/CD certifications to become a deployment ninja.3. AI & ML Engineers:Begin with foundational theory, then explore specializations in deep learning, model deployment, and real-world ML toolkits.4. Data & Site reliability engineers:Go from data processing to orchestration, with SREs focusing more on observability, reliability, and production-grade systems.5. Cybersecurity & Network Engineers:Pathways include threat detection, infrastructure hardening, and secure architecture design, essentials for protecting modern tech stacks.Certifications not only validate your skills but also help structure your learning journey, especially if you are self-taught or career-switching.Thinking of switching paths or leveling up your role?Which track are you eyeing in 2025?👉 Are you finding it difficult to land your next tech offer? It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Planning a tech career pivot in 2025? Start with the right certification path.Whether you are aiming to be a Cloud Engineer or diving into the world of AI/ML, the certification you choose can make or break your entry into the field.This blueprint maps out the most relevant certification paths based on your target role, so you are not just collecting badges, you are building a strategic, hire-ready profile.Here is how it is structured:1. Cloud & Platform Engineers:Start with system and container fundamentals, followed by multi-cloud and orchestration certs to build scalable systems.2. DevOps & MLOps Engineers:Focus on pipelines, automation, containerization, and CI/CD certifications to become a deployment ninja.3. AI & ML Engineers:Begin with foundational theory, then explore specializations in deep learning, model deployment, and real-world ML toolkits.4. Data & Site reliability engineers:Go from data processing to orchestration, with SREs focusing more on observability, reliability, and production-grade systems.5. Cybersecurity & Network Engineers:Pathways include threat detection, infrastructure hardening, and secure architecture design, essentials for protecting modern tech stacks.Certifications not only validate your skills but also help structure your learning journey, especially if you are self-taught or career-switching.Thinking of switching paths or leveling up your role?Which track are you eyeing in 2025?👉 Are you finding it difficult to land your next tech offer? It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Planning a tech career pivot in 2025? Start with the right certification path.Whether you are aiming to be a Cloud Engineer or diving into the world of AI/ML, the certification you choose can make or break your entry into the field.This blueprint maps out the most relevant certification paths based on your target role, so you are not just collecting badges, you are building a strategic, hire-ready profile.Here is how it is structured:1. Cloud & Platform Engineers:Start with system and container fundamentals, followed by multi-cloud and orchestration certs to build scalable systems.2. DevOps & MLOps Engineers:Focus on pipelines, automation, containerization, and CI/CD certifications to become a deployment ninja.3. AI & ML Engineers:Begin with foundational theory, then explore specializations in deep learning, model deployment, and real-world ML toolkits.4. Data & Site reliability engineers:Go from data processing to orchestration, with SREs focusing more on observability, reliability, and production-grade systems.5. Cybersecurity & Network Engineers:Pathways include threat detection, infrastructure hardening, and secure architecture design, essentials for protecting modern tech stacks.Certifications not only validate your skills but also help structure your learning journey, especially if you are self-taught or career-switching.Thinking of switching paths or leveling up your role?Which track are you eyeing in 2025?👉 Are you finding it difficult to land your next tech offer? It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Here’s what you need to know!𝐑𝐨𝐥𝐞𝐬 & 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬:𝗣𝗖𝗕 𝗟𝗮𝘆𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗗𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿 𝗘𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗶𝗰𝘀:- Design multi-layer PCBs for high-power motor controllers, DC-DC converters, inverters, and battery management systems (BMS).- Optimize power planes, creepage & clearance distances, and thermal dissipation for high-voltage (>96V) and high-current applications.- Ensure low-inductance routing, controlled impedance, and effective grounding strategies for high-power circuits.- Select appropriate PCB materials (FR4, Rogers, Polyimide, etc.) for high-reliability applications.- Implement EMI/EMC best practices, including shielding, filtering, and differential pair routing.𝗣𝗖𝗕 𝗟𝗮𝘆𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗥𝗙 & 𝗛𝗶𝗴𝗵-𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝗗𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻𝘀:- Design PCBs for RF modules, antennas, and high-speed signal transmission (GHz range).- Implement microstrip, stripline, coplanar waveguides, and controlled impedance routing.- Optimize layouts for minimum crosstalk, reflection, and insertion loss.- Work closely with RF engineers for layout optimization, grounding, and signal integrity enhancements.- Conduct EMI simulations and compliance testing to meet RF regulatory standards.𝗣𝗖𝗕 𝗟𝗮𝘆𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗔𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗼𝗴 & 𝗠𝗶𝘅𝗲𝗱-𝗦𝗶𝗴𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗖𝗶𝗿𝗰𝘂𝗶𝘁𝘀:- Design low-noise, precision analog circuit layouts, including op-amps, ADCs, DACs, and sensor interfaces.- Implement star-grounding, guard rings, and Kelvin sensing techniques for ultra-low- noise performance.- Optimize high-precision data acquisition and mixed-signal PCB layouts.- Ensure minimized parasitic capacitance and inductance in sensitive analog circuits.𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗹 & 𝗠𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀:- Design thermal vias, heat sinks, copper pours, and metal core PCBs (MCPCB) for high-power applications.- Work closely with mechanical engineers to optimize PCB integration within enclosures and cooling solutions.- Work closely with CFTs to perform thermal simulations and power dissipation analysis for PCB heat management.Design Validation & Compliance:- Perform DFM (Design for Manufacturability), DFA (Design for Assembly), and DFT (Design for Testability) analysis.- Collaborate with fabrication and assembly vendors to ensure high-yield production.- Ensure compliance with IPC standards (IPC-2221, IPC-600, IPC-6012), EMI/EMC regulations, and automotive/industrial safety norms.Apply now or let your hashtag#network know of this hashtag#opportunity by It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Start with the right certification path.Whether you are aiming to be a Cloud Engineer or diving into the world of AI/ML, the certification you choose can make or break your entry into the field.This blueprint maps out the most relevant certification paths based on your target role, so you are not just collecting badges, you are building a strategic, hire-ready profile.Here is how it is structured:1. Cloud & Platform Engineers:Start with system and container fundamentals, followed by multi-cloud and orchestration certs to build scalable systems.2. DevOps & MLOps Engineers:Focus on pipelines, automation, containerization, and CI/CD certifications to become a deployment ninja.3. AI & ML Engineers:Begin with foundational theory, then explore specializations in deep learning, model deployment, and real-world ML toolkits.4. Data & Site reliability engineers:Go from data processing to orchestration, with SREs focusing more on observability, reliability, and production-grade systems.5. 📢 Exciting opportunities await! Ready to take your hashtag#career to the next level? Here’s what you need to know!𝐑𝐨𝐥𝐞𝐬 & 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬:𝗣𝗖𝗕 𝗟𝗮𝘆𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗗𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿 𝗘𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗶𝗰𝘀:- Design multi-layer PCBs for high-power motor controllers, DC-DC converters, inverters, and battery It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Here’s what you need to know!𝐑𝐨𝐥𝐞𝐬 & 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬:𝗣𝗖𝗕 𝗟𝗮𝘆𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗗𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿 𝗘𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗶𝗰𝘀:- Design multi-layer PCBs for high-power motor controllers, DC-DC converters, inverters, and battery management systems (BMS).- Optimize power planes, creepage & clearance distances, and thermal dissipation for high-voltage (>96V) and high-current applications.- Ensure low-inductance routing, controlled impedance, and effective grounding strategies for high-power circuits.- Select appropriate PCB materials (FR4, Rogers, Polyimide, etc.) for high-reliability applications.- Implement EMI/EMC best practices, including shielding, filtering, and differential pair routing.𝗣𝗖𝗕 𝗟𝗮𝘆𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗥𝗙 & 𝗛𝗶𝗴𝗵-𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝗗𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻𝘀:- Design PCBs for RF modules, antennas, and high-speed signal transmission (GHz range).- Implement microstrip, stripline, coplanar waveguides, and controlled impedance routing.- Optimize layouts for minimum crosstalk, reflection, and insertion loss.- Work closely with RF engineers for layout optimization, grounding, and signal integrity enhancements.- Conduct EMI simulations and compliance testing to meet RF regulatory standards.𝗣𝗖𝗕 𝗟𝗮𝘆𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗔𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗼𝗴 & 𝗠𝗶𝘅𝗲𝗱-𝗦𝗶𝗴𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗖𝗶𝗿𝗰𝘂𝗶𝘁𝘀:- Design low-noise, precision analog circuit layouts, including op-amps, ADCs, DACs, and sensor interfaces.- Implement star-grounding, guard rings, and Kelvin sensing techniques for ultra-low- noise performance.- Optimize high-precision data acquisition and mixed-signal PCB layouts.- Ensure minimized parasitic capacitance and inductance in sensitive analog circuits.𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗹 & 𝗠𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀:- Design thermal vias, heat sinks, copper pours, and metal core PCBs (MCPCB) for high-power applications.- Work closely with mechanical engineers to optimize PCB integration within enclosures and cooling solutions.- Work closely with CFTs to perform thermal simulations and power dissipation analysis for PCB heat management.Design Validation & Compliance:- Perform DFM (Design for Manufacturability), DFA (Design for Assembly), and DFT (Design for Testability) analysis.- Collaborate with fabrication and assembly vendors to ensure high-yield production.- Ensure compliance with IPC standards (IPC-2221, IPC-600, IPC-6012), EMI/EMC regulations, and automotive/industrial safety norms.Apply now or let your hashtag#network know of this hashtag#opportunity by It took us 10 months to grow Rise from $0 to $40k ARR.In 2025, I spent 1000 hours studying how to run ads. With no agency help (all done alone), we bootstrapped from $40k to $1M ARR in 100 days.Here's what I learned:𝟭. 𝗔𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 (𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲) 𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗻𝗼𝗻-𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.All work you do in the highest level of abstraction (e.g. idea) to the lowest level (e.g. video editing), has a learning curve.𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.As you work, you climb up the learning curve. You soon hit a local maxima which limits your output due to lack of knowledge. And there's a global maxima which is the absolute ceiling of the channel.𝟯. 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮. 𝗦𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁.Local maxima can be approximated by experiments and existing data. But no one knows the global maxima since it's non-deterministic.This is therefore the most important role of founders:1) identify channel with highest global maxima,2) unlock local maxima,3) climb the curve as fast as possible.𝟰. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.You think in "This thing is too hard". But if you think in learning curve, you’re not very far away from that cracked engineer friend you know.𝟱. 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶-𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗺𝗮𝘅𝗶𝗺𝗮.You climb the curve by working.The unit to produce work is either time or money (to buy other people’s time).By multi-tasking you spread your finite resources (time) across different channels, which slow down compounding. The only acceptable case to multitask is when you hit global maxima, or you’re identifying local maxima to all-in in one channel.𝟲. 𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗰𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.You can borrow people’s progress (their distance climbed) by hiring them.𝟳. 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗶𝘀𝗱𝗼𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯 𝗮 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲.Learning curve is universal but how fast we climb a curve is different. It’s a mix of practice and gift.𝟴. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗮 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗶𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱.Companies in different countries are climbing the same curve, but countries usually have their own specialised learning curve where they’re leading other markets for at least 3 years. See the US in semi conductor, China in live streaming commerce.𝟵. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗳𝘂𝗹.Not all channel’s learning curve progress translate to commercial value, but climbing are equally difficult. So choose wisely which to climb.

Planning a tech career pivot in 2025? Start with the right certification path.Whether you are aiming to be a Cloud Engineer or diving into the world of AI/ML, the certification you choose can make or break your entry into the field.This blueprint maps out the most relevant certification paths based on your target role, so you are not just collecting badges, you are building a strategic, hire-ready profile.Here is how it is structured:1. Cloud & Platform Engineers:Start with system and container fundamentals, followed by multi-cloud and orchestration certs to build scalable systems.2. DevOps & MLOps Engineers:Focus on pipelines, automation, containerization, and CI/CD certifications to become a deployment ninja.3. AI & ML Engineers:Begin with foundational theory, then explore specializations in deep learning, model deployment, and real-world ML toolkits.4. Data & Site reliability engineers:Go from data processing to orchestration, with SREs focusing more on observability, reliability, and production-grade systems.5. Cybersecurity & Network Engineers:Pathways include threat detection, infrastructure hardening, and secure architecture design, essentials for protecting modern tech stacks.Certifications not only validate your skills but also help structure your learning journey, especially if you are self-taught or career-switching.Thinking of switching paths or leveling up your role?Which track are you eyeing in 2025?👉 Are you finding it difficult to land your next tech offer?
